name: Lower Respiratory Infections
description: Pneumonia, bronchitis, and lower airway infections

conditions.name: Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP)
conditions.shortDescription: Acute infection of the pulmonary parenchyma acquired outside the hospital

content.clinical_presentation: Fever, cough (productive OR non-productive), dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, tachypnea, hypoxemia. Physical exam may reveal crackles, bronchial breath sounds, OR dullness to percussion.
content.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical symptoms + radiographic infiltrate (chest X-ray OR CT) + exclusion of alternative diagnoses.
red_flags: Hypotension (SBP <90 mmHg)
Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
Altered mental status
Multilobar infiltrates
Septic shock

content.when_to_test: All patients with suspected CAP should have chest imaging. Blood cultures and sputum cultures recommended for hospitalized patients, especially those with severe CAP OR risk factors for MDRO.
conditional_tests: Sputum Gram stain and culture (if productive cough)
content.turnaround_time: Blood cultures: 24-48 hours. Urinary antigens: 1-2 hours. Respiratory PCR: 1-4 hours.

likely_pathogens: Haemophilus influenzae (10-20%, more common in COPD)
content.resistance_patterns: Macrolide resistance in S. pneumoniae: 20-40% in some regions. Penicillin resistance: 30-40% (but cephalosporins remain effective for pneumonia). H. influenzae: 30-40% produce beta-lactamase.
mdro_risk_factors: Recent antibiotic use within 90 days (any class)

resistance_considerations.global_trends: MRSA prevalence declining in many regions (10-20% of S. aureus isolates). ESBL-producing Enterobacterales increasing in healthcare-associated pneumonia.
resistance_considerations.high_risk_populations: Prior antibiotics within 90 days significantly increases resistance risk across all pathogen classes.

first_line.mild_outpatient: Amoxicillin 1g PO TID OR Doxycycline 100mg PO BID
first_line.moderate_outpatient: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg PO BID + Azithromycin 500mg PO x1, then 250mg daily
first_line.severe_hospitalized: Ceftriaxone 1-2g IV daily + Azithromycin 500mg IV daily OR Levofloxacin 750mg IV daily

content.alternatives: Beta-lactam allergy: Levofloxacin OR moxifloxacin monotherapy
content.avoid_list: Avoid fluoroquinolones if recent use (90 days) OR high local resistance

penicillin_susceptible.first_line: Penicillin G 2-4 million units IV q4h OR Amoxicillin 1g PO q8h

penicillin_resistant.mic_4_to_8: Ceftriaxone 2g IV q24h OR Levofloxacin 750mg IV/PO q24h
penicillin_resistant.mic_greater_than_8: Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h OR Linezolid 600mg IV/PO q12h
penicillin_resistant.note: Penicillin resistance does NOT predict cephalosporin resistance for pneumonia

haemophilus_influenzae.beta_lactamase_positive: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg PO q12h OR Ceftriaxone 1g IV q24h

legionella.first_line: Levofloxacin 750mg IV/PO q24h OR Azithromycin 500mg IV/PO q24h
legionella.note: Fluoroquinolones preferred over macrolides for severe disease

MRSA.duration: 7-14 days (minimum 7 days after last positive culture)
MRSA.note: Consider necrotizing pneumonia - may need longer duration

pseudomonas_aeruginosa.first_line: Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h OR Cefepime 2g IV q8h
pseudomonas_aeruginosa.severe: Add aminoglycoside (tobramycin 5-7mg/kg IV q24h) for first 3-5 days

content.de_escalation: Switch to narrow-spectrum oral therapy once clinically stable and pathogen identified
content.IV_to_po_switch: Criteria: Afebrile >24h, hemodynamically stable, improving symptoms, able to take PO

content.short_course: 5 days if clinically stable and afebrile
content.prolonged: 7-14 days for severe CAP, bacteremia, OR complications (empyema, abscess)

procalcitonin.initiation: <0.25 ng/mL: consider withholding antibiotics (low probability of bacterial infection)
procalcitonin.stopping: Decrease >80% from peak OR <0.25 ng/mL: safe to stop antibiotics
procalcitonin.evidence: Reduces antibiotic duration by 2-3 days without increasing mortality (multiple RCTs)
procalcitonin.limitations: Not validated in immunocompromised, not widely available

CRP.stopping: Decrease >50% from peak suggests clinical response
CRP.note: Less specific than procalcitonin, but more widely available

content.renal_dose: Adjust beta-lactams and fluoroquinolones for CrCl <30 mL/min
content.pregnancy: Preferred: Amoxicillin, ceftriaxone, azithromycin. Avoid: Fluoroquinolones, doxycycline
content.obesity: Consider higher doses of beta-lactams (e.g., ceftriaxone 2g daily)

hiv_cd4_less_than_200.additional_pathogens: PCP (Pneumocystis jirovecii), Cryptococcus, Mycobacterium avium complex
hiv_cd4_less_than_200.empiric_coverage: Add TMP-SMX 15-20mg/kg/day (TMP component) IV divided q6-8h for PCP coverage
hiv_cd4_less_than_200.diagnostic_tests: Induced sputum OR bronchoscopy with BAL for PCP, fungal, mycobacterial cultures

neutropenia_less_than_500.empiric_coverage: Broad-spectrum beta-lactam + aminoglycoside + voriconazole OR amphotericin B
neutropenia_less_than_500.diagnostic_tests: CT chest (halo sign, air crescent sign), serum galactomannan, BAL

solid_organ_transplant.timeline: <1 month: nosocomial bacteria. 1-6 months: CMV, PCP, Aspergillus. >6 months: community pathogens
solid_organ_transplant.prophylaxis: TMP-SMX for PCP, valganciclovir for CMV (first 3-6 months)
solid_organ_transplant.note: Always consider drug interactions with immunosuppressants (tacrolimus, cyclosporine)

black_box_warnings: Tendon rupture (especially Achilles) - risk increased with age >60, corticosteroids, transplant
Aortic aneurysm/dissection - avoid in patients with known aneurysm OR risk factors
drug_interactions: QTc prolongation: avoid with other QT-prolonging drugs (azithromycin, amiodarone)
Antacids/iron: reduce absorption - separate by 2-4 hours
fluoroquinolones.when_to_avoid: Reserve for Pseudomonas OR penicillin-allergic patients. NOT first-line for CAP.

macrolides.qtc_prolongation: Azithromycin can prolong QTc - avoid in patients with QTc >450ms OR on other QT drugs
drug_interactions: Statins: increased risk of rhabdomyolysis (especially with clarithromycin)

vancomycin.nephrotoxicity: Monitor trough levels (target 15-20 mcg/mL for pneumonia). Avoid concurrent nephrotoxins (NSAIDs, aminoglycosides).
vancomycin.red_man_syndrome: Infuse over 60-90 minutes to prevent histamine release

imaging_follow_up.routine_follow_up: Chest X-ray at 6 weeks for all patients >50 years OR smokers (rule out underlying malignancy)
imaging_follow_up.early_follow_up: Repeat CXR at 48-72h if: no clinical improvement, worsening symptoms, OR concern for complications
ct_indications: Failure to improve after 72h of appropriate antibiotics
Recurrent pneumonia in same location (rule out obstruction)
imaging_follow_up.resolution_time: Radiographic resolution lags clinical improvement: 4-6 weeks for young patients, 12 weeks for elderly/COPD

clinical_pearls: Sputum Gram stain is underutilized - can guide early therapy if quality specimen (>25 PMNs, <10 epithelial cells per LPF)
Procalcitonin <0.25 ng/mL has 90% NPV for bacterial pneumonia - consider stopping antibiotics
Parapneumonic effusion in 40% of CAP - tap if >1cm on lateral decubitus film
Failure to improve by 72h: consider resistant organism, empyema, PE, OR non-infectious mimic
POst-obstructive pneumonia: always follow-up CXR at 6 weeks to rule out underlying malignancy
CURB-65 score ≥2 OR PSI class IV-V: consider hospitalization
Legionella: think of travel, water exposure, hyponatremia, elevated LFTS

content.avoid_unnecessary_cultures: Outpatient CAP: Cultures not routinely needed
timeout_checklist: Switch IV to PO when appropriate
content.IV_to_po_opportunities: Most patients can switch to PO by day 2-3 if clinically stable

references.label: WHO Guidelines for Management of Pneumonia

conditions.name: Hospital-Acquired Pneumonia (HAP) / Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP)
conditions.shortDescription: Pneumonia occurring ≥48 hours after hospital admission OR intubation

content.clinical_presentation: New OR progressive infiltrate on chest imaging + clinical signs (fever, leukocytosis, purulent sputum, hypoxemia)
content.diagnostic_criteria: HAP: ≥48h after admission. VAP: ≥48h after intubation. Clinical + radiographic evidence.
red_flags: Septic shock
Rapid progression
Multidrug-resistant organisms
Immunosuppression

content.when_to_test: All patients: Obtain lower respiratory tract cultures before starting antibiotics
conditional_tests: MRSA nasal PCR (negative predictive value for MRSA pneumonia)

content.resistance_patterns: High rates of ESBL (20-40%), carbapenem resistance (5-20%), and MRSA (15-30%) in ICUs. Pseudomonas: 20-30% resistant to cefepime/piperacillin-tazobactam.
mdro_risk_factors: Prior IV antibiotics within 90 days (strongest predictor)

resistance_considerations.global_trends: Carbapenem-resistant Enterobacterales (CRE) increasing globally (5-20% in some regions). Extensively drug-resistant (XDR) Pseudomonas and Acinetobacter emerging.
resistance_considerations.high_risk_populations: ICU patients with prolonged hospitalization (>7 days) and multiple antibiotic courses have 50-70% risk of MDRO.

first_line.no_mdro_risk: Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h OR Cefepime 2g IV q8h OR Meropenem 1g IV q8h
first_line.mdro_risk: Antipseudomonal beta-lactam (pip-tazo, cefepime, OR meropenem) + Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h OR Linezolid 600mg IV q12h

content.alternatives: If carbapenem-resistant: Ceftazidime-avibactam, meropenem-vaborbactam, OR polymyxin-based regimen
content.avoid_list: Avoid monotherapy in severe HAP/VAP with MDRO risk

MRSA.first_line: Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h (target trough 15-20 mcg/mL for pneumonia)
MRSA.alternative: Linezolid 600mg IV/PO q12h (preferred if vancomycin MIC ≥1.5 OR renal dysfunction)
MRSA.note: Linezolid has better lung penetration than vancomycin; consider for severe VAP

pseudomonas_aeruginosa.first_line: Cefepime 2g IV q8h OR Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h (based on susceptibility)
pseudomonas_aeruginosa.alternative: Meropenem 1g IV q8h OR Aztreonam 2g IV q8h (if beta-lactam allergy)
pseudomonas_aeruginosa.severe: Consider combination therapy (beta-lactam + aminoglycoside OR fluoroquinolone) for first 3-5 days
pseudomonas_aeruginosa.note: Always check susceptibilities - resistance rates 20-30% for cefepime/pip-tazo

esbl_klebsiella.first_line: Meropenem 1g IV q8h OR Ertapenem 1g IV q24h (if not Pseudomonas)
esbl_klebsiella.note: Avoid cephalosporins and piperacillin-tazobactam even if susceptible in vitro

cre_carbapenem_resistant.first_line: Ceftazidime-avibactam 2.5g IV q8h OR Meropenem-vaborbactam 4g IV q8h
cre_carbapenem_resistant.alternative: Polymyxin B 2.5mg/kg loading, then 1.5mg/kg q12h + Tigecycline 100mg loading, then 50mg q12h
cre_carbapenem_resistant.note: Consult infectious disease specialist. Consider combination therapy for severe infections.

acinetobacter_baumannii.first_line: Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g IV q6h (if susceptible) OR Polymyxin B-based regimen
acinetobacter_baumannii.alternative: Tigecycline 100mg loading, then 50mg IV q12h + Carbapenem (if susceptible)
acinetobacter_baumannii.note: Often XDR - consult ID. Inhaled colistin may be adjunctive therapy.

content.de_escalation: Narrow to single agent once pathogen identified and susceptibilities known. Stop MRSA coverage if cultures negative and MRSA nasal PCR negative.
content.IV_to_po_switch: Limited PO options for HAP/VAP; most require full IV course. Linezolid and fluoroquinolones have excellent bioavailability if PO switch needed.

content.short_course: 7 days if good clinical response and susceptible pathogen
content.prolonged: 14 days for non-fermenting GNRs (Pseudomonas, Acinetobacter), MRSA with bacteremia, OR slow clinical response

procalcitonin.stopping: Decrease >80% from peak OR <0.5 ng/mL: consider stopping antibiotics at day 7
procalcitonin.evidence: Safe to shorten duration in HAP/VAP with good clinical response (multiple RCTs)
procalcitonin.limitations: Not validated for MDRO infections OR immunocompromised patients

clinical_stability_criteria.note: If all criteria met at day 7, consider stopping antibiotics (even if radiographic improvement incomplete)

content.renal_dose: Adjust all beta-lactams, vancomycin, and aminoglycosides for renal function. Use CRRT dosing if on continuous renal replacement therapy.
content.obesity: Use actual body weight for vancomycin loading dose (25-30mg/kg); consider extended infusion beta-lactams (cefepime 2g over 4h, pip-tazo 4.5g over 4h)
content.immunocompromised: Consider fungal coverage (voriconazole, amphotericin B) if risk factors present (neutropenia, transplant, prolonged corticosteroids)

vancomycin.nephrotoxicity: Monitor trough levels q3-4 days. Target 15-20 mcg/mL for pneumonia. Avoid concurrent nephrotoxins (aminoglycosides, NSAIDs, contrast).

linezolid.serotonin_syndrome: Avoid with SSRIs, SNRIs, MAOIs. Risk of serotonin syndrome.
linezolid.myelosuppression: Monitor CBC weekly. Thrombocytopenia and anemia common after 2 weeks.
linezolid.note: No renal dose adjustment needed - advantage in renal failure

Polymyxins.nephrotoxicity: Occurs in 30-60% of patients. Monitor SCr daily. Avoid other nephrotoxins.
Polymyxins.neurotoxicity: Paresthesias, dizziness, ataxia. Reduce dose in renal dysfunction.

clinical_pearls: MRSA nasal PCR negative has 95% NPV for MRSA pneumonia - stop empiric MRSA coverage if negative
Endotracheal aspirate (ETA) is non-inferior to BAL for diagnosis - less invasive
Ventilator bundle reduces VAP: HOB elevation, daily sedation vacation, oral care with chlorhexidine
Failure to improve by day 3: consider resistant organism, empyema, OR non-infectious mimic (ARDS, PE, CHF)
Double Pseudomonas coverage (beta-lactam + aminoglycoside/fluoroquinolone) does NOT improve outcomes - use monotherapy once susceptible
Acinetobacter and Stenotrophomonas: often XDR - consult ID early

timeout_checklist: De-escalate MRSA coverage if cultures negative and MRSA PCR negative
De-escalate to monotherapy if single pathogen identified
content.IV_to_po_opportunities: Limited; most HAP/VAP requires full IV course

references.label: IDSA/ATS Hospital-Acquired and Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia Guidelines (2016)

conditions.name: Healthcare-Associated Pneumonia (HCAP)
conditions.shortDescription: Pneumonia in patients with recent healthcare exposure (nursing home, dialysis, home infusion, hospitalization within 90 days)

content.definition: Pneumonia occurring in patients with recent healthcare contact: nursing home residents, hospitalization within 90 days, home infusion therapy, chronic dialysis within 30 days, OR immunosuppression.
content.clinical_presentation: Similar to CAP: fever, cough, dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain. Higher risk of multidrug-resistant organisms (MDRO) compared to CAP.
risk_factors: Home wound care OR IV therapy
content.note: The HCAP designation was removed from 2016 IDSA/ATS HAP/VAP guidelines due to poor predictive value for MDRO. Current approach: individualized risk assessment for MDRO rather than blanket HCAP category.

essential_tests: Sputum Gram stain and culture (high yield for MDRO)
content.severity_assessment: Use CURB-65 OR PSI to determine admission need. Consider ICU admission for severe sepsis, respiratory failure, OR hemodynamic instability.

common_pathogens: Gram-negative bacilli (E. coli, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas aeruginosa)
content.resistance_patterns: MRSA prevalence 10-30% in HCAP. Pseudomonas risk increased with structural lung disease (bronchiectasis, COPD) OR prior fluoroquinolone use.

options: Ceftriaxone 1-2g IV q24h + Azithromycin 500mg IV/PO q24h
Levofloxacin 750mg IV/PO q24h (monotherapy)
Ceftriaxone 1-2g IV q24h + Doxycycline 100mg PO q12h
Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h (target trough 15-20) + Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h
Linezolid 600mg IV/PO q12h + Cefepime 2g IV q8h
Vancomycin + Meropenem 1g IV q8h (if prior carbapenem-resistant organism)
high_mdro_risk.note: Add azithromycin 500mg IV q24h if atypical coverage needed (Legionella risk)

content.de_escalation: De-escalate based on culture results and clinical response within 48-72 hours. Discontinue MRSA coverage if MRSA-negative cultures and clinical improvement.

content.strep_pneumoniae: Ceftriaxone 1-2g IV q24h OR Penicillin G 2-4 MU IV q4h (if susceptible)
content.MRSA: Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h OR Linezolid 600mg IV/PO q12h
content.pseudomonas: Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h OR Cefepime 2g IV q8h OR Meropenem 1g IV q8h
content.h_influenzae: Ceftriaxone 1-2g IV q24h OR Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g IV q6h
content.klebsiella_esbl: Meropenem 1g IV q8h OR Ertapenem 1g IV q24h
content.IV_to_po_switch: Switch to PO when: afebrile >24h, hemodynamically stable, improving clinically, able to take PO, functioning GI tract

content.standard_duration: 5-7 days for most patients with good clinical response
content.extended_duration: 7-14 days for: MRSA pneumonia, Pseudomonas pneumonia, bacteremic pneumonia, slow clinical response, immunocompromised
content.procalcitonin_guided: Consider procalcitonin-guided therapy: stop antibiotics when PCT <0.25 ng/mL OR decreased by 80% from peak

content.renal_impairment: Adjust doses for beta-lactams, vancomycin, fluoroquinolones. Avoid aminoglycosides if possible. Monitor vancomycin trough levels.
content.hepatic_impairment: Use caution with linezolid (risk of lactic acidosis). Avoid tigecycline in severe hepatic dysfunction.
content.pregnancy: Preferred: Ceftriaxone + Azithromycin. Avoid fluoroquinolones, doxycycline, aminoglycosides.
content.immunocompromised: Broader coverage needed. Consider fungal (Aspergillus, Pneumocystis) and viral (CMV) etiologies. Consult infectious disease specialist.

red_flags: Empiric MRSA/Pseudomonas coverage without risk factors
Continuation of broad-spectrum antibiotics beyond 48-72h without positive cultures
Failure to de-escalate based on culture results
Treatment duration >7 days without clear indication
IV_to_po_criteria: Oxygen saturation >90% on room air OR baseline
Able to take and absorb oral medications
content.antibiotic_timeout: Perform 48-72 hour review: Are cultures positive? Is patient improving? Can we narrow spectrum? Can we switch to PO? Can we stop antibiotics?

conditions.name: Aspiration Pneumonia
conditions.shortDescription: Pneumonia resulting from aspiration of oropharyngeal OR gastric contents into the lower respiratory tract

content.definition: Aspiration pneumonia: bacterial infection following aspiration of colonized oropharyngeal secretions. Aspiration pneumonitis: chemical injury from gastric acid (Mendelson syndrome) - does NOT require antibiotics.
content.clinical_presentation: Fever, cough (often productive with foul-smelling sputum), dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain. Infiltrates typically in dependent lung segments (right lower lobe, posterior segments).
content.key_distinction: Aspiration pneumonitis (chemical injury) presents acutely (<2h) with dyspnea, tachypnea, hypoxemia but NO fever initially. Aspiration pneumonia (bacterial infection) develops over 24-48h with fever and purulent sputum.

essential_tests: Chest X-ray (look for infiltrates in dependent segments: RLL, posterior segments)
CBC with differential (leukocytosis suggests bacterial infection)
conditional_tests: Sputum Gram stain and culture (if productive cough)
CT chest (if complicated by abscess OR empyema)
Modified barium swallow OR FEES (fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing)
content.diagnostic_stewardship: Do NOT treat aspiration pneumonitis (chemical injury) with antibiotics. Only treat if bacterial infection is suspected (fever, purulent sputum, leukocytosis, infiltrate persisting >48h).

common_pathogens: Oral anaerobes (Peptostreptococcus, Prevotella, Bacteroides) - role controversial
content.anaerobic_coverage_controversy: Current evidence (2024) does NOT support routine anaerobic coverage. Anaerobes rarely isolated from aspiration pneumonia cultures. Reserve anaerobic coverage for lung abscess OR empyema.
content.community_vs_healthcare: Community-acquired aspiration: typical CAP pathogens. Healthcare-associated aspiration: higher risk of MRSA and Pseudomonas.

community_acquired.regimen: Treat as CAP - NO routine anaerobic coverage needed
options: Ceftriaxone 1-2g IV q24h + Azithromycin 500mg IV/PO q24h
Levofloxacin 750mg IV/PO q24h (monotherapy)
Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g IV q6h (if mild, provides some anaerobic coverage)

healthcare_associated.regimen: Broader coverage for MRSA/Pseudomonas if risk factors present
options: Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h + Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h
Linezolid 600mg IV/PO q12h + Cefepime 2g IV q8h

anaerobic_coverage_indications.when_to_add: Only if: lung abscess, empyema, necrotizing pneumonia, OR putrid sputum
options: Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g IV q6h
Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h
Clindamycin 600-900mg IV q8h (add to beta-lactam)

content.note: Avoid unnecessary anaerobic coverage (clindamycin, metronidazole) unless clear indication. Overuse contributes to C. difficile risk.

content.strep_pneumoniae: Ceftriaxone 1-2g IV q24h OR Penicillin G 2-4 MU IV q4h
content.MRSA: Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h OR Linezolid 600mg IV/PO q12h
content.pseudomonas: Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h OR Cefepime 2g IV q8h
content.anaerobes: Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g IV q6h OR Clindamycin 600-900mg IV q8h
content.de_escalation: Narrow spectrum based on culture results. Discontinue anaerobic coverage if no abscess/empyema and clinical improvement.
content.IV_to_po_switch: Switch when clinically stable: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg PO q12h OR Levofloxacin 750mg PO q24h

content.standard_duration: 5-7 days for uncomplicated aspiration pneumonia with good clinical response
content.extended_duration: 7-14 days for: complicated pneumonia, bacteremia, slow clinical response, immunocompromised
content.lung_abscess: 3-4 weeks IV therapy, then switch to PO for total 6-8 weeks (see Lung Abscess module)
stopping_criteria: Able to take oral medications safely (swallowing evaluation)
No evidence of abscess OR empyema

prevention_strategies: Swallowing evaluation and dysphagia management (reduces recurrence by 50%)
Elevate head of bed 30-45 degrees during feeding and for 30-60 min after
Oral hygiene (tooth brushing BID, chlorhexidine mouthwash) - reduces bacterial load
Avoid sedatives and anticholinergics when possible
Consider PEG tube if recurrent aspiration (controversial - does NOT prevent aspiration)
Treat GERD if present (but PPIs may INCREASE aspiration risk by altering gastric pH)
content.renal_impairment: Adjust beta-lactam doses. Monitor vancomycin levels. Avoid aminoglycosides.
content.pregnancy: Preferred: Ampicillin-sulbactam OR Ceftriaxone + Azithromycin. Avoid fluoroquinolones.
content.immunocompromised: Consider broader coverage and longer duration. Rule out fungal (Aspergillus) OR viral (CMV) etiologies.
clinical_pearls: Witnessed aspiration + infiltrate in dependent segment (RLL, posterior segments) = aspiration pneumonia
Anaerobic coverage is OVERUSED - reserve for lung abscess OR empyema
Swallowing evaluation reduces recurrent aspiration by 50%
Proton pump inhibitors INCREASE aspiration pneumonia risk (alter gastric pH, promote bacterial overgrowth)
Tube feeding does NOT prevent aspiration - consider post-pyloric feeding if recurrent
Foul-smelling sputum suggests anaerobes - but still rare in aspiration pneumonia without abscess
Aspiration pneumonitis (chemical injury) resolves in 48-72h without antibiotics - do NOT treat empirically

red_flags: Treating aspiration pneumonitis (chemical injury) with antibiotics - NOT indicated
Routine anaerobic coverage without lung abscess OR empyema
Prolonged antibiotic therapy (>7 days) without clear indication
Failure to perform swallowing evaluation to prevent recurrence
key_stewardship_points: Aspiration pneumonitis does NOT require antibiotics (supportive care only)
Anaerobic coverage NOT routinely needed for aspiration pneumonia
Treat as CAP unless healthcare-associated risk factors present
Address underlying aspiration risk (dysphagia, GERD, oral hygiene)
content.antibiotic_timeout: 48-72h review: Is this bacterial infection OR chemical pneumonitis? Are cultures positive? Can we narrow spectrum? Can we stop anaerobic coverage?

conditions.name: Lung Abscess
conditions.shortDescription: Necrotic cavity within the lung parenchyma containing purulent material, typically >2cm in diameter

content.definition: Lung abscess: necrotic cavity (>2cm) with air-fluid level on imaging, containing purulent material. Necrotizing pneumonia: multiple small (<2cm) abscesses within consolidated lung.
content.clinical_presentation: Subacute onset (weeks): fever, productive cough with foul-smelling/putrid sputum, weight loss, night sweats, pleuritic chest pain, hemoptysis. Chronic symptoms distinguish from acute pneumonia.
risk_factors: POor oral hygiene OR periodontal disease
content.complications: Empyema, bronchopleural fistula, massive hemoptysis, septic emboli, brain abscess

essential_tests: Chest X-ray (thick-walled cavity with air-fluid level)
CT chest with contrast (defines size, location, complications)
Sputum Gram stain and culture (if productive)
conditional_tests: Bronchoscopy with BAL (if sputum non-diagnostic, rule out malignancy)
Echocardiography (rule out endocarditis if septic emboli suspected)
content.imaging_features: Chest X-ray: thick-walled cavity (>4mm) with air-fluid level, typically in dependent segments (posterior upper lobes, superior lower lobes). CT: better defines size, multilocularity, pleural involvement.

pathogens: Streptococcus milleri group (S. anginosus, S. constellatus, S. intermedius)

content.note: Anaerobic cultures often negative due to fastidious organisms. Putrid sputum is pathognomonic for anaerobes.

first_line: Clindamycin 600-900mg IV q8h + Ceftriaxone 2g IV q24h
alternative: Meropenem 1g IV q8h (if severe OR failed initial therapy)

options: Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h + Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h
Linezolid 600mg IV/PO q12h + Meropenem 1g IV q8h

content.immunocompromised: Add antifungal coverage (voriconazole OR amphotericin B) if fungal abscess suspected. Consider Nocardia (TMP-SMX).
content.note: Metronidazole monotherapy is INADEQUATE (poor activity against aerobic streptococci). Always combine with beta-lactam OR use combination agent.

content.anaerobes: Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g IV q6h OR Clindamycin 600-900mg IV q8h OR Metronidazole 500mg IV q8h (with beta-lactam)
content.strep_milleri: Penicillin G 2-4 MU IV q4h OR Ceftriaxone 2g IV q24h
content.MRSA: Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h OR Linezolid 600mg IV/PO q12h
content.klebsiella: Ceftriaxone 2g IV q24h OR Meropenem 1g IV q8h (if ESBL)
content.pseudomonas: Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h OR Cefepime 2g IV q8h OR Meropenem 1g IV q8h
content.nocardia: TMP-SMX 5mg/kg (TMP component) IV q6-8h for 6-12 months
content.IV_to_po_switch: Switch after clinical improvement (afebrile, decreasing cavity size on imaging): Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg PO q12h OR Clindamycin 450mg PO q6h

content.standard_duration: Prolonged therapy required: 3-4 weeks IV, then switch to PO for total 6-8 weeks
content.extended_duration: Large abscesses (>6cm), slow response, OR immunocompromised: 8-12 weeks total
content.monitoring: Serial chest X-rays every 2-4 weeks to document cavity resolution. CT chest if no improvement after 4-6 weeks.
stopping_criteria: Radiographic improvement (decreasing cavity size, resolving air-fluid level)
Complete cavity resolution not required before stopping antibiotics
content.note: Radiographic resolution lags clinical improvement by weeks to months. Do not prolong antibiotics solely for persistent cavity if clinically improved.

surgical_indications: Failure of medical therapy after 4-6 weeks
content.percutaneous_drainage: Consider CT-guided drainage for large (>4-6cm) peripheral abscesses not responding to antibiotics. Contraindicated if high bleeding risk OR central location.
content.bronchoscopy: Therapeutic bronchoscopy for drainage rarely effective. Mainly diagnostic (rule out obstruction, obtain cultures).
content.renal_impairment: Adjust beta-lactam and vancomycin doses. Avoid aminoglycosides.
content.pregnancy: Preferred: Ampicillin-sulbactam OR Piperacillin-tazobactam. Avoid fluoroquinolones, metronidazole (1st trimester).

red_flags: Metronidazole monotherapy (inadequate for aerobic streptococci)
Inadequate anaerobic coverage (e.g., ceftriaxone alone)
Premature switch to PO before clinical stability
Prolonged IV therapy beyond 3-4 weeks without clear indication
Failure to obtain cultures before starting antibiotics
key_stewardship_points: Always provide anaerobic coverage for primary lung abscess
Prolonged therapy (6-8 weeks total) is necessary - do not stop prematurely
Switch to PO after 3-4 weeks IV if clinically improving
Radiographic resolution lags clinical improvement - do not over-treat
Consider surgical consultation if no improvement after 4-6 weeks
content.antibiotic_timeout: Weekly review: Is patient improving clinically? Are cultures positive? Can we narrow spectrum? Is cavity size decreasing? Ready for IV-to-PO switch?

references.label: Johns Hopkins ABX Guide - Lung Abscess

conditions.name: Acute Bronchitis
conditions.shortDescription: Self-limited inflammation of the bronchi, typically viral, presenting with acute cough lasting <3 weeks

content.definition: Acute bronchitis: self-limited inflammation of the large airways (bronchi) causing acute cough, typically lasting 1-3 weeks. Predominantly viral etiology (>90%).
content.clinical_presentation: Acute cough (productive OR non-productive) lasting <3 weeks, with OR without sputum production. May have low-grade fever, wheezing, chest discomfort. NO signs of pneumonia (no focal consolidation, no hypoxemia).
content.key_distinction: Acute bronchitis vs pneumonia: Bronchitis has NO focal consolidation on chest X-ray, NO hypoxemia, NO tachypnea, NO high fever (>38.5°C). If these present, consider pneumonia.
content.bacterial_etiology: Rare (<10%): Bordetella pertussis (whooping cough), Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumoniae

content.clinical_diagnosis: Acute bronchitis is a CLINICAL diagnosis. Routine testing is NOT recommended for uncomplicated cases.
when_not_to_test: No chest X-ray needed if: age <65, HR <100, RR <24, temp <38°C, no focal consolidation on exam
No sputum culture (not helpful - often colonization)
No procalcitonin (not validated for acute bronchitis)
No routine viral testing (does not change management)
when_to_test: Chest X-ray: if pneumonia suspected (focal findings, hypoxemia, high fever, tachypnea)
Influenza testing: if influenza season and <48h symptom onset (antiviral eligible)
Pertussis testing (PCR OR culture): if paroxysmal cough, post-tussive emesis, inspiratory whoop, OR exposure
COVID-19 testing: if compatible symptoms and local prevalence
content.diagnostic_stewardship: Avoid unnecessary testing. Chest X-ray and labs do NOT reduce antibiotic prescribing and increase costs.

content.viral_predominance: Viruses cause >90% of acute bronchitis cases. Bacterial superinfection is rare.
content.color_of_sputum_myth: Purulent (green/yellow) sputum does NOT indicate bacterial infection. Sputum color is due to neutrophil peroxidase, not bacteria. Do NOT use sputum color to guide antibiotic prescribing.
content.pertussis: Bordetella pertussis: paroxysmal cough lasting >2 weeks, post-tussive emesis, inspiratory whoop. More common in adolescents/adults with waning immunity.
content.atypical_bacteria: Mycoplasma pneumoniae and Chlamydia pneumoniae: cause prolonged cough (>3 weeks) but rarely require treatment in immunocompetent adults.

content.antibiotics_not_recommended: Antibiotics are NOT recommended for routine acute bronchitis in healthy adults. No benefit in symptom duration OR severity. Increases adverse effects and antibiotic resistance.
symptomatic_treatment: Cough suppressants: Dextromethorphan 10-20mg PO q4-6h PRN
NSAIDs: Ibuprofen 400mg PO q6-8h OR Acetaminophen 500-1000mg PO q6h PRN
Honey: 1-2 teaspoons for cough (evidence-based, especially in children >1 year)

when_to_consider_antibiotics.pertussis_confirmed: Azithromycin 500mg PO day 1, then 250mg PO days 2-5 (OR 500mg PO daily x3 days)
when_to_consider_antibiotics.pertussis_suspected: Treat if <3 weeks of symptoms (reduces transmission) OR high-risk contacts (infants, pregnant women)
when_to_consider_antibiotics.copd_exacerbation: See AECOPD module - antibiotics indicated if increased dyspnea + increased sputum purulence + increased sputum volume

content.influenza: Oseltamivir 75mg PO q12h x5 days if <48h symptom onset and high-risk patient OR severe illness

pertussis.first_line: Azithromycin 500mg PO day 1, then 250mg PO days 2-5 (total 5 days)
alternatives: TMP-SMX DS 1 tab PO q12h x14 days (if macrolide allergy)
pertussis.note: Antibiotics do NOT improve symptoms if >3 weeks of cough. Treat to reduce transmission.

mycoplasma_chlamydia.indication: Only if prolonged symptoms (>3 weeks) and high suspicion
options: Azithromycin 500mg PO day 1, then 250mg PO days 2-5
Doxycycline 100mg PO q12h x7-10 days

content.viral: Supportive care only. Antibiotics NOT indicated.

content.natural_history: Acute cough typically lasts 1-3 weeks. 50% of patients still coughing at 2 weeks, 25% at 3 weeks. This is NORMAL and does NOT indicate bacterial infection.
content.when_to_reassess: Reassess if: cough persists >3 weeks, worsening symptoms, new fever, dyspnea, hemoptysis, OR weight loss. Consider alternative diagnoses (pneumonia, pertussis, asthma, GERD, post-nasal drip).

content.copd_patients: Acute bronchitis in COPD patients may represent AECOPD. See AECOPD module for antibiotic indications (Anthonisen criteria).
content.immunocompromised: Lower threshold for chest X-ray and antibiotics. Consider atypical pathogens (fungi, PCP).
content.pregnancy: Symptomatic treatment preferred. If antibiotics needed: Azithromycin OR Amoxicillin. Avoid doxycycline, fluoroquinolones.
content.elderly: Higher risk of pneumonia. Lower threshold for chest X-ray if fever, tachypnea, OR hypoxemia.
content.pertussis_contacts: POst-exposure prophylaxis: Azithromycin 500mg PO day 1, then 250mg PO days 2-5 for close contacts (especially infants, pregnant women).

red_flags: Prescribing antibiotics for uncomplicated acute bronchitis (viral illness)
Using sputum color (green/yellow) to justify antibiotics
Ordering chest X-ray OR labs for low-risk patients (increases antibiotic prescribing)
Prescribing fluoroquinolones OR broad-spectrum antibiotics for acute bronchitis
key_stewardship_messages: Acute bronchitis is viral in >90% of cases - antibiotics NOT indicated
Purulent sputum does NOT mean bacterial infection
Cough lasting 1-3 weeks is NORMAL for acute bronchitis
Patient education is key: 'Antibiotics will not help your cough and may cause harm'
Offer symptomatic treatment (cough suppressants, NSAIDs, honey)
content.patient_education: Explain: 'Your cough is caused by a virus. Antibiotics do not work against viruses and will not make you feel better faster. They can cause side effects like diarrhea and allergic reactions. Your cough should improve in 1-3 weeks with rest and symptomatic treatment.'
content.delayed_prescribing: Consider delayed antibiotic prescription strategy: 'Fill this prescription only if your symptoms worsen OR do not improve after 7 days.' Reduces antibiotic use by 30-40%.

conditions.name: Acute Exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD)
conditions.shortDescription: Acute worsening of respiratory symptoms in COPD patients beyond normal day-to-day variation, requiring change in medication

content.definition: AECOPD: acute worsening of respiratory symptoms (dyspnea, cough, sputum production/purulence) beyond normal day-to-day variation, requiring change in regular medication.
content.clinical_presentation: Increased dyspnea, increased sputum volume, increased sputum purulence (Anthonisen criteria). May have fever, wheezing, chest tightness, fatigue.

anthonisen_criteria.type_1_severe: All 3 cardinal symptoms: increased dyspnea + increased sputum volume + increased sputum purulence
anthonisen_criteria.type_3_mild: 1 cardinal symptom + ≥1 of: URTI in past 5 days, fever, increased wheezing, increased cough, increased HR/RR

triggers: Viral infections (50-70%): rhinovirus, influenza, RSV, coronavirus
Bacterial infections (40-50%): H. influenzae, S. pneumoniae, M. catarrhalis, P. aeruginosa
Non-infectious: heart failure, pulmonary embolism, pneumothorax, medication non-adherence

content.clinical_diagnosis: AECOPD is primarily a clinical diagnosis based on symptom worsening.
essential_tests: Pulse oximetry OR ABG (assess hypoxemia, hypercapnia)
Chest X-ray (rule out pneumonia, pneumothorax, heart failure)
conditional_tests: Sputum Gram stain and culture (if purulent sputum, frequent exacerbations, OR ICU admission)
BNP OR pro-BNP (if heart failure suspected)
D-dimer and CT angiography (if PE suspected)

severity_assessment.mild: Increased symptoms, no respiratory failure, outpatient management
severity_assessment.moderate: Increased symptoms, no respiratory failure, hospitalization needed
severity_assessment.severe: Respiratory failure (hypoxemia, hypercapnia, acidosis) OR ICU admission

bacterial_pathogens: Pseudomonas aeruginosa (5-10% - risk factors: severe COPD, frequent exacerbations, recent antibiotics, bronchiectasis)

when_to_use_antibiotics.indicated: Anthonisen Type 1 (all 3 symptoms) OR Type 2 (2 of 3 symptoms) exacerbations
when_to_use_antibiotics.also_indicated: Severe exacerbation requiring mechanical ventilation (invasive OR non-invasive)
when_to_use_antibiotics.not_indicated: Anthonisen Type 3 (1 symptom) exacerbations - treat with bronchodilators and corticosteroids only

no_pseudomonas_risk: Azithromycin 500mg PO day 1, then 250mg PO days 2-5

pseudomonas_risk: Meropenem 1g IV q8h (if prior carbapenem-resistant organism)

content.duration: 5 days for most patients (non-inferior to 7-14 days). Extend to 7 days if slow response OR Pseudomonas.

content.h_influenzae: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg PO q12h OR Ceftriaxone 1g IV q24h
content.s_pneumoniae: Amoxicillin 1g PO q8h OR Ceftriaxone 1g IV q24h
content.m_catarrhalis: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg PO q12h OR Azithromycin 500mg PO q24h
content.pseudomonas: Ciprofloxacin 500-750mg PO q12h OR Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h OR Cefepime 2g IV q8h
content.de_escalation: Narrow spectrum based on culture results. Switch to PO when clinically stable.
content.note: Most AECOPD are viral OR non-infectious. Do not prolong antibiotics beyond 5 days without clear indication.

content.antibiotic_duration: 5 days for most AECOPD (non-inferior to longer courses)
content.extended_duration: 7 days if: Pseudomonas infection, slow clinical response, severe exacerbation requiring ICU
content.corticosteroid_duration: Prednisone 40mg PO daily x5 days (equivalent to longer courses with fewer side effects)
content.note: Longer antibiotic courses (>7 days) do NOT improve outcomes and increase adverse effects and resistance.

bronchodilators.saba: Albuterol 2.5-5mg nebulized q4-6h OR 2-4 puffs MDI q4-6h
bronchodilators.sama: Ipratropium 0.5mg nebulized q6h OR 2-4 puffs MDI q6h
bronchodilators.combination: Albuterol-ipratropium nebulized q4-6h (more effective than either alone)

corticosteroids.regimen: Prednisone 40mg PO daily x5 days OR Methylprednisolone 125mg IV q6h x72h then taper
corticosteroids.note: Longer courses (>5-7 days) increase adverse effects without additional benefit

content.oxygen_therapy: Target SpO2 88-92% (avoid hyperoxia - risk of CO2 retention)

ventilatory_support.niv: Non-invasive ventilation (BiPAP) for: pH 7.25-7.35, PaCO2 >45 mmHg, RR >25
ventilatory_support.invasive: Intubation for: pH <7.25, severe hypoxemia, altered mental status, respiratory arrest

prevention: Inhaled corticosteroids + LABA for frequent exacerbators (≥2 per year)

red_flags: Prescribing antibiotics for Anthonisen Type 3 exacerbations (1 symptom only)
Using fluoroquinolones as first-line without Pseudomonas risk factors
Antibiotic duration >5-7 days without clear indication
Failure to use corticosteroids (more important than antibiotics for AECOPD)
Using sputum color alone to justify antibiotics
key_stewardship_points: Not all AECOPD require antibiotics - use Anthonisen criteria
5 days of antibiotics is sufficient for most patients
Corticosteroids are MORE important than antibiotics for AECOPD
Avoid fluoroquinolones unless Pseudomonas risk factors present
Sputum purulence alone does NOT indicate bacterial infection
content.antibiotic_timeout: 48-72h review: Is patient improving? Are cultures positive? Can we stop antibiotics at day 5? Are corticosteroids being used appropriately?

conditions.name: Bronchiectasis with Acute Infection
conditions.shortDescription: Permanent dilation of bronchi with recurrent infections, characterized by chronic productive cough and frequent exacerbations

content.definition: Bronchiectasis: permanent, abnormal dilation of bronchi due to chronic inflammation and infection. Characterized by chronic productive cough, recurrent respiratory infections, and progressive lung damage.
content.clinical_presentation: Chronic daily productive cough with purulent sputum, recurrent respiratory infections, dyspnea, hemoptysis, fatigue, weight loss. Acute exacerbation: increased sputum volume/purulence, worsening dyspnea, fever.
content.exacerbation_criteria: ≥3 of: increased sputum volume, increased sputum purulence, increased dyspnea, increased cough, fever, malaise, reduced lung function, radiographic changes

essential_tests: High-resolution CT chest (gold standard for diagnosis - shows bronchial dilation, signet ring sign)
Sputum Gram stain and culture (essential for pathogen identification)
conditional_tests: Immunoglobulin levels (IgG, IgA, IgM, IgE) - rule out immunodeficiency
Aspergillus IgE and precipitins (rule out ABPA)
Sweat chloride test (rule out CF in young patients)
Rheumatoid factor, ANA (rule out connective tissue disease)
Mycobacterial cultures (if endemic area OR risk factors)
content.severity_assessment: Bronchiectasis Severity Index (BSI) OR FACED score to predict exacerbations and mortality

common_pathogens: Pseudomonas aeruginosa (20-30% - associated with worse outcomes)
content.chronic_colonization: Pseudomonas aeruginosa chronic colonization (≥2 positive cultures ≥3 months apart) associated with: more frequent exacerbations, accelerated lung function decline, increased mortality
content.nontuberculous_mycobacteria: NTM (M. avium complex, M. abscessus) in 10-20% of bronchiectasis patients. Suspect if: refractory symptoms, cavitary disease, nodular infiltrates. Requires prolonged multi-drug therapy.
content.aspergillus: Aspergillus fumigatus colonization common. ABPA if: elevated IgE, eosinophilia, positive Aspergillus IgE/precipitins, central bronchiectasis.

no_pseudomonas: Azithromycin 500mg PO day 1, then 250mg PO days 2-14

pseudomonas_colonized: Consider dual anti-pseudomonal therapy: beta-lactam + aminoglycoside OR fluoroquinolone

content.duration: 14 days for most exacerbations (longer than CAP/AECOPD due to impaired clearance). Extend to 21 days if Pseudomonas OR slow response.
content.note: Always obtain sputum culture before starting antibiotics. Tailor therapy based on prior culture results and local resistance patterns.

content.h_influenzae: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg PO q12h OR Ceftriaxone 2g IV q24h

pseudomonas.IV: Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h OR Cefepime 2g IV q8h OR Meropenem 1g IV q8h
pseudomonas.dual_therapy: Consider for severe infection OR MDR: beta-lactam + aminoglycoside (tobramycin 5-7mg/kg IV q24h) OR + ciprofloxacin

content.MRSA: Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h OR Linezolid 600mg IV/PO q12h
content.s_pneumoniae: Amoxicillin 1g PO q8h OR Ceftriaxone 2g IV q24h
content.m_catarrhalis: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg PO q12h OR Azithromycin 500mg PO q24h
content.ntm: Consult infectious disease specialist. Typically: Azithromycin + Ethambutol + Rifampin for M. avium complex (12-18 months)

content.acute_exacerbation: 14 days for most pathogens. Extend to 21 days for Pseudomonas OR slow clinical response.

options: Azithromycin 250-500mg PO 3x/week (reduces exacerbations by 40-50%)
Inhaled tobramycin 300mg nebulized q12h (28 days on, 28 days off) for Pseudomonas
Inhaled colistin 1-2 MU nebulized q12h for MDR Pseudomonas
chronic_suppressive_therapy.monitoring: Baseline and periodic: audiometry (azithromycin), renal function (aminoglycosides), sputum cultures, ECG (QTc prolongation)

stopping_criteria: Return to baseline sputum volume and purulence

airway_clearance.essential: Daily airway clearance is cornerstone of bronchiectasis management
mucolytics: Hypertonic saline 7% nebulized q12h (improves mucus clearance)
Dornase alfa (DNase) - only for CF-related bronchiectasis

content.surgical_indications: Localized disease with recurrent infections OR massive hemoptysis refractory to medical therapy. Lung transplant for end-stage disease.

red_flags: Treating chronic colonization (positive culture without symptoms) - NOT indicated
Inadequate treatment duration (<14 days) for acute exacerbations
Failure to obtain sputum cultures before starting antibiotics
Empiric anti-pseudomonal therapy without prior Pseudomonas colonization
Long-term suppressive antibiotics without clear indication (≥3 exacerbations/year)
key_stewardship_points: Chronic colonization does NOT require treatment - only treat symptomatic exacerbations
Always obtain sputum culture to guide therapy
Airway clearance is MORE important than antibiotics for long-term management
content.chronic_suppressive_therapy_criteria: Only use if ≥3 exacerbations per year despite optimal airway clearance. Monitor for resistance and adverse effects.
content.antibiotic_timeout: Weekly review: Is patient improving? Are cultures back? Can we narrow spectrum? Is duration appropriate (14 days)? Is airway clearance optimized?

streptococcus_pneumoniae.epidemiology: Most common bacterial cause of CAP (30-40%). Incidence decreased with PCV13/PCV20 vaccination.
streptococcus_pneumoniae.clinical_clues: Rust-colored sputum, lobar consolidation on CXR, bacteremia in 20-30% of hospitalized patients
streptococcus_pneumoniae.resistance: Penicillin resistance 30-40% (but cephalosporins still effective for pneumonia). Macrolide resistance 20-40%.
streptococcus_pneumoniae.treatment: Penicillin-susceptible: Penicillin G OR Amoxicillin. Penicillin-resistant: Ceftriaxone OR Levofloxacin.
streptococcus_pneumoniae.prevention: PCV20 (single dose) OR PCV15 + PPSV23 (1 year apart) for adults ≥65 years OR immunocompromised
streptococcus_pneumoniae.note: Penicillin MIC ≤2 mcg/mL is still treatable with high-dose penicillin OR ceftriaxone for pneumonia

haemophilus_influenzae.epidemiology: 10-20% of CAP, more common in COPD patients and smokers
haemophilus_influenzae.clinical_clues: Purulent sputum, COPD exacerbation, chronic bronchitis, non-typeable strains most common
haemophilus_influenzae.treatment: Beta-lactamase negative: Ampicillin. Beta-lactamase positive: Amoxicillin-clavulanate OR Ceftriaxone.
haemophilus_influenzae.prevention: Hib vaccine (children), smoking cessation, COPD management
haemophilus_influenzae.note: Non-typeable H. influenzae (NTHi) not covered by Hib vaccine - common in COPD exacerbations

legionella_pneumophila.epidemiology: 2-8% of CAP, higher in outbreaks (water systems, cooling towers, travel)
legionella_pneumophila.clinical_clues: Hyponatremia, elevated LFTS, diarrhea, relative bradycardia, travel/water exposure history
legionella_pneumophila.resistance: Rare - fluoroquinolones and macrolides remain highly effective
legionella_pneumophila.treatment: Levofloxacin 750mg q24h (preferred for severe) OR Azithromycin 500mg q24h
legionella_pneumophila.prevention: Water system maintenance, avoid hot tubs/whirlpools in immunocompromised
legionella_pneumophila.note: Urinary antigen test detects only L. pneumophila serogroup 1 (70% of cases) - negative test does not rule out

mrsa_methicillin_resistant_staph_aureus.epidemiology: 10-20% of S. aureus isolates, declining in many regions. Risk factors: IVDU, recent hospitalization, hemodialysis
mrsa_methicillin_resistant_staph_aureus.clinical_clues: Necrotizing pneumonia, cavitation, empyema, post-influenza pneumonia, IVDU
mrsa_methicillin_resistant_staph_aureus.resistance: Resistant to all beta-lactams except ceftaroline. Vancomycin MIC creep (MIC 1.5-2) associated with treatment failure.
mrsa_methicillin_resistant_staph_aureus.treatment: Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg q8-12h (target trough 15-20) OR Linezolid 600mg q12h (better lung penetration)
mrsa_methicillin_resistant_staph_aureus.prevention: Contact precautions, decolonization (mupirocin nasal + chlorhexidine baths) for recurrent infections
mrsa_methicillin_resistant_staph_aureus.note: MRSA nasal PCR negative has 95% NPV for MRSA pneumonia - can stop empiric coverage if negative

pseudomonas_aeruginosa.epidemiology: 20-30% of HAP/VAP, rare in CAP except in bronchiectasis/COPD with prior colonization
pseudomonas_aeruginosa.clinical_clues: Structural lung disease (bronchiectasis, COPD), prior antibiotics, healthcare exposure, green sputum
pseudomonas_aeruginosa.resistance: 20-30% resistant to cefepime/piperacillin-tazobactam. Carbapenem resistance 10-20%. XDR strains emerging.
pseudomonas_aeruginosa.treatment: Cefepime 2g q8h OR Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g q6h OR Meropenem 1g q8h (based on susceptibility)
pseudomonas_aeruginosa.prevention: Avoid unnecessary antibiotics, optimize airway clearance in bronchiectasis
pseudomonas_aeruginosa.note: Double coverage (beta-lactam + aminoglycoside/fluoroquinolone) does NOT improve outcomes - use monotherapy once susceptible

klebsiella_pneumoniae.epidemiology: 10-20% of HAP/VAP, classic 'currant jelly' sputum in alcoholics (rare now)
klebsiella_pneumoniae.clinical_clues: Healthcare exposure, diabetes, alcoholism, upper lobe cavitation (rare)
klebsiella_pneumoniae.resistance: ESBL production 20-40% in healthcare settings. Carbapenem resistance (KPC) 5-20% in endemic areas.
klebsiella_pneumoniae.treatment: ESBL: Meropenem OR Ertapenem. CRE: Ceftazidime-avibactam OR Meropenem-vaborbactam.
klebsiella_pneumoniae.prevention: Contact precautions for CRE, hand hygiene, antibiotic stewardship
klebsiella_pneumoniae.note: Avoid cephalosporins and piperacillin-tazobactam for ESBL even if susceptible in vitro (inoculum effect)

mycoplasma_pneumoniae.epidemiology: 10-20% of CAP, more common in younger patients (<40 years), outbreaks in closed communities
mycoplasma_pneumoniae.clinical_clues: Gradual onset, dry cough, extrapulmonary manifestations (rash, hemolytic anemia, myocarditis)
mycoplasma_pneumoniae.resistance: Macrolide resistance increasing (10-30% in some regions, especially Asia)
mycoplasma_pneumoniae.treatment: Azithromycin 500mg x1, then 250mg q24h OR Doxycycline 100mg q12h OR Levofloxacin 750mg q24h
mycoplasma_pneumoniae.note: Atypical pathogen - not visible on Gram stain, no cell wall (beta-lactams ineffective)

anaerobes_oral_flora.epidemiology: Historically thought common in aspiration pneumonia, but rarely isolated in modern studies
anaerobes_oral_flora.clinical_clues: Foul-smelling sputum, lung abscess, empyema, necrotizing pneumonia, poor dentition
anaerobes_oral_flora.treatment: Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g q6h OR Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g q6h OR Clindamycin 600-900mg q8h
anaerobes_oral_flora.note: Routine anaerobic coverage NOT recommended for aspiration pneumonia - only for lung abscess OR empyema
